page.lettertext:
fol.345r
Belgia: 1590: Decem
b
Belgia 1590 24 Decem
b
To M
r
Bodly
S
r
. It is soe longe since I wroate unto yowe for that havinge
soe manie thinges to doe that I kepe noe Copies of my letters unto yowe
as I dowbt yowe will thine I have not received anie letters of late,
And therefore thowgh their be not manie I have received from yowe: yet
I will geve yowe knowledge by this what theie be.
The first as I thinke unawnsweared is of the xijth of November, whereby
appeareth that yowe received from the
generall States
Copies of the
whole Negotiac
o
n w
th
the Scottishe Ambassad
r
for
Collonell Steward
,
w
ch
I have received and perused, and in mine opinion the awnsweares
made by the States beinge indifferentlie reported to the
K.
owght to move
him to revoke the leter of Mark grawnted for the said Collonell: And
as I see the Content
of the same awnsweares are advisedly [compiled]
and w
th
good Reverence towardes the Kinge, delivered. The Ambassad
rs
was heare before the date of yo
r
l
re
, and made me in sum part ac-
quainted w
th
his opinion against the Colonels proceedinge.
That w
ch
was promised yowe by the
Greffier
for the awnsweare to
hir
Ma
tie
I see was performed by yo
r
last letters.
Wheare yowe require to have a Cipher, I doe at this present send
yowe one, not verie curiouslie made for avoidinge of trowble to us both
but yet sufficeint to
s
rve o
r
purpose, and maie be augmented as yowe
see Cawse./
Yo
r
next letter is of the xix
th
of November, By w
ch
yowe doe certifie
the Retorne of the Pentioner of whome yowe advertised mee the 28
of October, and the third of November: This matter is such as I cannot
treate w
th
yowe at this present untill yowe have received yo
r
Cipher
lookinge also to heare more particularities thereof when yowe have
received my Cipher for soe yo
r
self dothe make mention./
Yo
r
last letter is of the vij
th
of this monethe, whearewith yowe have
sent unto mee the awnsweare of the States to the thing
proposed by
yowe and
M
r
Wilkes
: The w
ch
I have partlie perused, but not sene
thorowghlie for lacke of leisure as I meane to doe: Theie have taken
good time both to make theire awnsweares, and to deliver them: for where
yo
r
proposit
o
ns weare the xx
th
of Julye, theare awnsweares are
dated the xv
th
of October: And for the deliverie theie have taken time
from the xv
th
of October, to the vj
th
of December./ And nowe abowt
the xxij
th
theare be Commissioners cum, whereof two seme to cum
from
Holland
, and the other two from
Zeland
: And be heare devideth
in theire lodging
a sonder, but yet I thinke theie will joine in theyr
Negotiation: theie pretend owtwardlie to cum to procure Relaxation of
fol.345v
Belgia: 1590: De
c
:
their Shippes, and restiuc
o
n of their good
: The first being done
absolutelie longer, before theire comminge: The other as farreforthe done
as theie could be fownd extant: But yet uppon Bond that if the good
weare proved Spanishe, the vallue should be awnsweared, whereof
S
r
John
Hawkins
being newlie retorned from the Seas offreth to make good proof of
a great part of the same./
Mons
r
de Charon
by authoritie owt of
Zeland did deale in thes Courses as
Ortel
was wont to doe, but I perceive
by him that he is not like to be authorised anie further, whearein thowgh he
be well Contented, yet the States are not well [advised] to omitt him, for
that he is wise and acceptable heare unto us. Thes w
ch
be comm
from Holland have required to be hard nowe after the Hollidaies. For
sooner theie have not, whearebie I gesse theie will in the meane season
for howesoever theie be Clamorous against their Arrest
, theire aiding
and succoring of the
K. of Spaine
o
r
Common Ennemie to the strengthe-
ninge of him wth all warlike preparations
ar such as
t
wee weare better to bee
at warre w
th
divers of the townes of thos
Lowe Cuntries
, than under
Collo
r
of protec
o
n to suffer them to helpe o
r
Ennemie to make that
warre against us, w
th
owt the w
ch
he should not be hable almost to
cum to the Seas./ Thus have I awnsweared all the l
res
of yo
rs
that are cum to my hand. And nowe yowe shall understand
that uppon Advertisement
of the State of
Ostend
uppon sum Accident
of Notable
s
rvice latelie done by the Gouverno
r
theare to the great
hurt and dishonno
r
of the Ennemie, It is greatlie doubted that the
Ennemie will seeke sum mightie Revendge, and as wee heare, Bridges
and the Cuntrie theare abowt
being greatlie dammaged by the Garrison
of Ostend make great offers of Contribuc
o
n either to besiege Ostend,
or to fortefie abowt yt: uppon this Considerac
o
n hir Ma
tie
hath written
good rownd letters to the States, the Copie wheareof yow shall see
and in like manner an other letter to yowe, wheareof I neede make noe
Recitall, not dowbting but yowe will use expedic
o
n abowt the execuc
o
n
thereof, as her Ma
tie
hath geven yowe in Charge, and as yowe shall
proceade soe I praie yowe advertise respectivelie the Gouverno
rs
of
Flusshinge
and of Ostend./ If thes Commissioners that are
come shall not voluntarelie present the awnsweare of the States after
theire first Awdience, theie shall be charged thearew
th
, soe as wee
maie lett them understand howe farreforthe wee have Cowrse to mislike
not so much for the delaie w
ch
hath been great, as for the unreasonable
nes, and absurdnes of theire awnsweares./
I se
e
Co
u
t Moryce
followeth his flatter
y
g fortune, to tak upp
o
h
y
gouvm
e
t
of [.] th
a
I feare he c
a
be hable to ma
n
aug, be
y
g
subject to
e Controllm
e
t
of
e stat
.
I pray yow send me a list, of
e Co
u
sellors of
s state w
t
their quallities . 24
10br
1590
Yours very assuredly
W. Burghley
